• Tourism in Pakistan is recognized as the tourism industry's "next big thing" due to the country's diverse cultures, people, and landscapes attracting significant visitor interest.
• Pakistan has attracted a total of 90 million tourists, nearly doubling the number of tourists compared to a decade prior.
• Despite the growth in tourist numbers, Pakistan currently ranks 130th globally in terms of tourist income.
• The tourism industry in Pakistan has experienced a gradual decline in foreign tourists primarily due to the ongoing threat of terrorism within the country.
• The 2013 Nanga Parbat tourist shooting incident had a severe and adverse impact on Pakistan’s tourism sector, contributing to a downturn in tourist arrivals.
• As of 2016, tourism in Pakistan has begun a gradual recovery process, although the country remains ranked 130th worldwide in tourism income.
• Foreign investment in Pakistan significantly declined by 54.6% by the year 2010, primarily due to political instability and weak law and order, as reported by the Bank of Pakistan.

• Since 1999, Pakistan has overhauled its business regulations along liberal lines, removing most barriers to capital flow and international direct investment, allowing up to 100% equity participation in most sectors for foreign investors.
• Foreign investors in Pakistan face no restrictions on capital inflow, and unlimited remittance of profits, dividends, service fees, or capital is permitted.

• Despite regulatory liberalization, the ease of doing business in Pakistan has deteriorated over the past decade due to increasing political instability, domestic insurgency, insecurity, and widespread corruption.
• The World Bank's Ease of Doing Business Index has downgraded Pakistan’s ratings annually since September 2009, reflecting the growing difficulties in conducting business.

• The World Bank and International Finance Corporation's Ease of Doing Business Index 2020 ranked Pakistan 108th out of 190 countries, showing continuous improvement from 136th place the previous year.
• The top five countries in the Ease of Doing Business Index 2020 were New Zealand, Singapore, Denmark, Hong Kong, and South Korea.

• Improvements in Pakistan’s business environment and government investment-friendly policies have attracted interest from major international automobile companies, including France’s Renault, South Korea’s Hyundai and Kia, China’s JW Forland, and Germany’s Volkswagen, aiming to enter the Pakistani auto market via joint ventures with local manufacturers such as Dewan Farooque Motors, Khalid Mushtaq Motors, and United Motors.
• As of March 2022, only the joint venture between Hyundai and Nishat Motors had materialized among these proposed automotive collaborations.

• US oil and gas multinational Exxon Mobil re-entered the Pakistani market in May 2018 after nearly three decades, acquiring a 25% stake in offshore drilling operations, with initial surveys indicating potential for significant hydrocarbon reserves offshore.

• To support Pakistan’s unstable foreign-exchange reserves, Qatar pledged a $3 billion investment package comprising deposits and direct investments, with the first installment of $500 million transferred to Pakistan by the end of June 2019.

• The rapid growth of Pakistan's economy has attracted significant interest from foreign investors in the corporate sector, resulting in multinational groups acquiring majority stakes in various Pakistani corporations.
• Singapore-based Temasek Holdings acquired PICIC for $339 million, marking a notable foreign investment in Pakistan's financial sector.
• Standard Chartered Bank purchased Union Bank for $487 million, further exemplifying foreign acquisition activity in Pakistan’s banking industry.
• ABN Amro acquired Prime Commercial Bank for $228 million, demonstrating continued foreign interest in Pakistan’s commercial banking sector.
• China Mobile invested $460 million to acquire PakTel, indicating substantial foreign participation in Pakistan’s telecommunications industry.
• Etisalat acquired Pakistan Telecommunication Company Limited (PTCL) for $1.8 billion, representing one of the largest foreign investments in Pakistan’s telecom sector.
• Philip Morris International purchased an additional 57.6% shares of Lakson Tobacco Company for $382 million, expanding its stake in Pakistan’s tobacco industry.
• In 2016, Turkish appliance manufacturer Arçelik acquired Dawlance, a Pakistani home appliances company, for $243 million, highlighting foreign investment in Pakistan’s consumer goods sector.
• FrieslandCampina, a Dutch multinational dairy company, acquired a 51% stake in Engro Foods for $446.81 million in 2016, marking a significant foreign acquisition in Pakistan’s food industry.

• Also in 2016, The Abraaj Group sold its 66.4% stake in K-Electric, Pakistan’s largest private-sector power utility, to Shanghai Electric for $1.77 billion, reflecting major foreign investment in Pakistan’s energy sector.
• The foreign exchange inflows generated from these acquisitions and mergers are contributing to Pakistan’s ability to cover its current account deficit, thereby supporting macroeconomic stability.
• Pakistan achieved its highest export value of US$25.4 billion in the fiscal year (FY) 2011, marking a peak in its foreign trade performance.

• From FY 2014 to FY 2016, Pakistan experienced a 12.4 percent decline in exports, primarily due to an international commodity slump beginning in FY 2015, compounded by domestic structural supply-side constraints such as energy shortages, high input costs, and an overvalued exchange rate.
• The export growth trend during 2014-2016 paralleled global trade growth patterns, indicating external factors influenced Pakistan’s export performance.

• In FY 2017, Pakistan’s merchandise trade exports grew marginally by 0.1 percent despite continued stress in the external sector, whereas imports surged by 18.0 percent compared to the previous year, reflecting an imbalance in trade dynamics.
• The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) provides trade data on exports and imports, which may differ from figures compiled by the Pakistan Bureau of Statistics.

• Total exports (in billion US dollars) from FY 2008 to FY 2024 showed fluctuations: starting at 24.01 in FY 2008, peaking at 31.11 in FY 2011, declining to 27.43 in FY 2016, and rising again to 38.67 by FY 2024.
• Goods exports followed a similar pattern, reaching 25.37 billion in FY 2011, dipping to 21.97 billion in FY 2016, and recovering to 30.98 billion in FY 2024.
• Services exports increased from 3.56 billion in FY 2008 to 7.69 billion in FY 2024, with minor fluctuations throughout the period.
• Total imports (in billion US dollars) rose from 45.44 in FY 2008 to a peak of 84.49 in FY 2022, before declining to 63.96 in FY 2024, indicating a general upward trend with volatility.
• Goods imports increased from 35.28 billion in FY 2008 to 71.54 billion in FY 2022, then decreased to 53.16 billion in FY 2024.
• Services imports fluctuated between 6.99 billion in FY 2010 and 12.94 billion in FY 2022, settling at 10.80 billion in FY 2024.

• Pakistan’s trade deficit widened significantly over the years, starting at 21.43 billion in FY 2008, reaching a low of 12.46 billion in FY 2011, then expanding to 44.89 billion in FY 2022 before narrowing to 25.29 billion in FY 2024.

• The rising trend in Pakistan’s imports is attributed to increased economic activity linked to the China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), especially in the energy sector, where construction projects require heavy machinery imports.
• The current economic growth in Pakistan is driven by both investments and consumption, contributing to higher import levels.

• In FY 2018, Pakistan’s exports increased by 12.6 percent to US$24.8 billion compared to FY 2017, while imports rose by 16.2 percent to US$56.6 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of US$31.8 billion, the highest in a decade.
• Pakistan’s goods exports reached a record high of US$25.6 billion in FY 2021, surpassing the previous peak of US$25.3 billion recorded in FY 2011.
• Pakistan's major export commodities from fiscal year (FY) 2015 to FY 2024 are detailed in million US dollars, covering key sectors such as textiles, agriculture, chemicals, and manufactured goods.
• Knitwear exports increased from $2,264 million in FY 2015 to a peak of $4,516 million in FY 2022, before slightly declining to $4,018 million in FY 2024.
• Ready-made garments exports showed steady growth from $2,044 million in FY 2015 to $3,698 million in FY 2022, with a minor decrease to $3,471 million by FY 2024.
• Bed wear exports fluctuated, starting at $2,207 million in FY 2015, rising to $3,255 million in FY 2022, then decreasing to $2,790 million in FY 2024.
• Rice exports varied over the period, beginning at $2,038 million in FY 2015, dipping to $1,575 million in FY 2017, then rising to $3,684 million by FY 2024, marking significant growth.
• Cotton cloth exports declined overall, from $2,487 million in FY 2015 to $1,898 million in FY 2024, with a low point of $1,884 million in FY 2021.
• Chemical and pharmaceutical exports experienced moderate growth, starting at $1,250 million in FY 2015, reaching $1,482 million in FY 2022, and slightly decreasing to $1,420 million in FY 2024.
• Cotton yarn exports showed a downward trend from $1,818 million in FY 2015 to $1,052 million in FY 2024, with the lowest value of $870 million recorded in FY 2023.
• Towels exports increased from $716 million in FY 2015 to $1,080 million in FY 2022, followed by a slight decrease to $954 million in FY 2024.
• Leather manufactures exports fluctuated modestly, starting at $547 million in FY 2015, peaking at $649 million in FY 2022, and slightly declining to $606 million in FY 2024.
• Sports goods exports declined steadily from $585 million in FY 2015 to $439 million in FY 2024, with a consistent downward trend throughout the period.
• Surgical goods and medical instruments exports remained relatively stable, increasing from $401 million in FY 2015 to $480 million in FY 2021, then slightly decreasing to $456 million in FY 2024.

• Power generating machinery imports increased from $675 million in FY 2014 to a peak of $1,577 million in FY 2018, then declined to $795 million by FY 2022.
• During fiscal year (FY) 2017, Pakistan experienced significant pressure on its external account primarily due to an increase in imports of capital equipment and fuel.

• A reversal in global oil prices during FY 2017 led to an increase in petroleum, oil, and lubricants (POL) imports, which, combined with falling exports, caused the merchandise trade deficit to grow by 39.4 percent, reaching US$26.885 billion.

• Although remittances and Coalition Support Fund inflows declined slightly in FY 2017 compared to the previous year, the negative impact was offset by an improvement in the income account, mainly attributed to lower profit repatriations by oil and gas firms.
• The current account deficit further increased to US$19.2 billion in FY 2018, marking a continued external imbalance challenge for Pakistan.

• Despite the high current account deficit in FY 2018, the effect on foreign exchange reserves was not severe due to the availability of financial inflows that partially offset the deficit and helped maintain exchange rate stability.
• Net foreign direct investment (FDI) grew by 12.4 percent during a nine-month period in FY 2018, reaching US$1.6 billion, indicating increased investor confidence.
• Net foreign portfolio investment (FPI) inflows amounted to US$631 million in FY 2018, reversing the previous year's outflow of US$393 million.
• The period saw the completion of multiple merger and acquisition deals between local and foreign companies, signaling growing foreign investor interest in Pakistan.

• Several foreign automakers announced plans to enter the Pakistani market, with some forming joint ventures with local conglomerates, further demonstrating Pakistan’s attractiveness to foreign investors and a positive outlook for future FDI inflows.
• The Pakistani government successfully issued a US$1.0 billion Sukuk in the international capital market at a notably low interest rate of 5.5 percent, reflecting favorable borrowing conditions.

• Pakistan continued to receive support from international financial institutions (IFIs) such as the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, as well as bilateral partners like China, during the post-Extended Fund Facility (EFF) period.
• Net official loan inflows amounted to US$1.1 billion during this period, contributing to the country’s external financing needs.
• By 4 May 2017, Pakistan’s foreign exchange reserves stood at US$20.8 billion, sufficient to finance approximately four months of import payments, indicating a relatively stable reserve position.
• The table of credit, debit, and net external account balances from FY 2008 to FY 2024 shows fluctuating trends:
• Credit (in billion US$) increased from 37.25 in FY 2008 to 72.45 in FY 2024.
• Debit (in billion US$) rose from 51.12 in FY 2008 to 74.14 in FY 2024.
• Net balances remained negative for most years, with a peak deficit of −19.20 billion US$ in FY 2018 and improving to −1.69 billion US$ by FY 2024.

• The net external balance as a percentage of GDP ranged from a deficit of −8.9% in FY 2008 to a low deficit of −0.6% in FY 2021, indicating some improvement in external imbalances relative to the size of the economy over time.

• Pakistan receives economic aid from multiple sources in the form of loans and grants, including international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank (WB), and Asian Development Bank (ADB).
• In addition to multilateral aid, Pakistan obtains bilateral aid from developed countries and oil-rich nations, making foreign aid a significant source of funding for the Pakistani economy.
• Securing foreign aid has been a consistent priority for nearly every Pakistani government, with the Prime Minister often leading delegations personally to negotiate and collect aid.
• The Asian Development Bank committed to providing approximately $6 billion in development assistance to Pakistan during the period 2006–2009.
• The World Bank launched a lending program of up to $6.5 billion for Pakistan under a new four-year aid strategy spanning 2006–2009, focusing largely on enhancing the country’s infrastructure.
• Japan pledged to provide $500 million annually in economic aid to Pakistan.
• In November 2008, the IMF approved a loan of $7.6 billion to Pakistan aimed at stabilizing and rebuilding the country’s economy.
• Between the fiscal years 2008 and 2010, the IMF extended loans totaling $5.2 billion to Pakistan.

• In 2011, the Pakistani government decided to sever ties with the IMF; however, the government elected in 2013 re-established these relations and negotiated a three-year $6.6 billion aid package to address ongoing debt challenges.
• In May 2019, Pakistan finalized a $6 billion foreign aid agreement with the IMF, marking the country’s 22nd bailout from the institution.
• The China–Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) is being developed primarily through concessionary loans from China under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI).

• The value of CPEC investments is difficult to quantify precisely in monetary terms as it encompasses decades of past and future industrial development and global economic influence, transcending conventional fiat currency valuation.

• Remittances from Pakistanis living abroad have been a crucial component of Pakistan's economy and foreign exchange reserves, with significant contributions from Pakistanis settled in Western Europe, North America, and since 1973, from workers in oil-rich Arab states.
• The Pakistani diaspora, numbering approximately 9 million individuals, contributed US$19.3 billion to Pakistan’s economy in the fiscal year (FY) 2017.

• Major source countries for remittances to Pakistan include the United Arab Emirates (UAE), United States (US), Saudi Arabia, Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries (Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman), Australia, Canada, Japan, Norway, Switzerland, United Kingdom (UK), and other European Union (EU) countries.

• In FY2017, remittances experienced a negative growth rate of 3.0% compared to the previous year, which had reached an all-time high of US$19.9 billion; this decline was primarily attributed to adverse economic conditions in Arabian and Gulf countries following the 2016 fall in oil prices.

• Positive developments such as the Qatar FIFA World Cup, Dubai Expo, Saudi Arabia’s Vision 2030 implementation, and the Pakistani Prime Minister’s recent visit to Kuwait are expected to create new employment opportunities and potentially improve remittance inflows in subsequent years.
• According to the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP), remittances increased significantly to US$29.4 billion in the year 2021.

• The government of Pakistan and the SBP implemented measures to encourage the use of formal channels for sending remittances, which, along with stable foreign exchange market conditions, contributed to the rise in remittance inflows.
• Despite the global economic challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic, remittances played a vital role in strengthening Pakistan’s external sector position.

• The remittance data, sourced from the State Bank of Pakistan and the Ministry of Finance, shows a steady increase in workers’ remittances over the years: from US$6.4 billion in FY2008 to US$30.3 billion in FY2024, with notable yearly figures including US$19.9 billion in FY2016, US$19.4 billion in FY2017, US$29.5 billion in FY2021, and US$31.3 billion in FY2022.

• Detailed remittance inflows by country for the fiscal year 2020/21 are as follows (in billion US$): Saudi Arabia (7.667), UAE (6.114), UK (4.067), Gulf Cooperation Council collectively (3.310), USA (2.754), European Union (2.709), Australia (0.594), Canada (0.586), Malaysia (0.204), Norway (0.111), Japan (0.085), Switzerland (0.041), and other countries combined (1.130).

• The 2022 Pakistan economic crisis was characterized by significant financial instability, reflected notably in the behavior of Pakistan government bonds across various maturities including 1 year, 5 year, 10 year, and 20 year terms.

• During the periods of 2019–2020 and again in 2022, Pakistan experienced an inverted yield curve, a financial phenomenon where shorter-term government bonds offered higher yields than longer-term bonds, indicating market expectations of economic downturn or increased risk.
• The inverted yield curve in Pakistan during these years was closely associated with rising inflation rates, which exerted pressure on the country’s economic stability and investor confidence.

• Inflation in Pakistan during this period was a critical factor influencing bond yields, with higher inflation eroding the real returns on fixed-income securities and compelling investors to demand higher yields for shorter maturities.

• The economic crisis and bond market conditions in Pakistan during 2019–2020 and 2022 reflected broader macroeconomic challenges, including fiscal deficits, currency depreciation, and external debt pressures that contributed to the overall financial distress.

• The interplay between inflation dynamics and bond yield curves in Pakistan during these years served as a key indicator of the underlying economic vulnerabilities and the market’s anticipation of future monetary policy adjustments by the State Bank of Pakistan.

• The 2022 economic crisis underscored the need for structural reforms and effective economic management to restore investor confidence and stabilize Pakistan’s financial markets amid persistent inflationary pressures and fiscal imbalances.

• Corruption remains a persistent problem within Pakistan's government, with various claims of anti-corruption initiatives particularly targeting government officials and lower levels of the police force.

• In 2011, Pakistan consistently ranked poorly on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI), with scores of 2.5 in 2011, 2.3 in 2010, and 2.5 in 2009, on a scale where 10 represents the least corrupt.
• In 2011, Pakistan was ranked 134th on the CPI, with 42 countries ranked worse in terms of perceived corruption.
• Pakistan’s CPI ranking declined further in 2012, dropping from 134th to 139th place, positioning it as the 34th most corrupt country globally, tied with Azerbaijan, Kenya, Nepal, and Nigeria.

• During the Sharif regime from 2013 to 2017, Pakistan’s CPI ranking improved significantly, reaching 117th out of 180 countries in 2017, with the score increasing progressively from 28 in 2013 to 32 in both 2016 and 2017.
• In 2017, Pakistan’s CPI score of 32 placed it equal to Egypt and ahead of 59 other countries in terms of perceived corruption.
• The National Accountability Bureau (NAB) was established in 1999 as a response to the detrimental effects of corruption on Pakistan’s economy and governance.
• NAB’s primary mandate is to recover looted money from corrupt individuals and entities and to deposit these funds into the national exchequer.
• Between 2018 and 2020, NAB achieved a record recovery of Rs 502 billion from corrupt elements.

• Since its inception, NAB has recovered a total of Rs 814 billion either directly or indirectly from corrupt sources, surpassing the recovery amounts of other comparable anti-corruption organizations globally.

• In 2017, Pakistan ranked 57th globally in public external debt according to the CIA World Factbook, with an estimated debt of approximately $107.527 billion in 2019, representing 67.1% of its GDP in 2017.
• The primary source for Pakistan’s government debt and liabilities data is the State Bank of Pakistan.
• Gross public debt in Pakistan increased steadily from 9,010 billion PKR in June 2010 to 71,246 billion PKR projected for June 2024.
• Total government debt rose from 8,411 billion PKR in June 2010 to an estimated 65,080 billion PKR by June 2024.
• Public external debt in US dollars fluctuated from $53.6 billion in June 2010, peaking at $100.0 billion in June 2022, and was projected at $98.3 billion in June 2024.
• As a percentage of GDP, gross public debt ranged from 58.9% in June 2011 to a high of 76.6% in June 2019, with a projected decline to 67.2% by June 2024.
• Total government debt as a percentage of GDP varied from 54.3% in June 2011 to a peak of 69.9% in June 2019, with a forecasted decrease to 61.4% by June 2024.
• Public external debt as a percentage of GDP decreased from 30.8% in June 2010 to 19.5% in June 2017, then rose again to 32.3% in June 2023, before an expected decline to 25.8% by June 2024.
• Pakistan’s external debt servicing involves repayment of both principal and accrued interest amounts.

• Principal repayments on external debt fluctuated over fiscal years, starting at $3,140 million in FY2010, peaking at $15,061 million in FY2023, and projected to decrease to $9,273 million in FY2024.
• Interest payments on external debt increased from $1,015 million in FY2010 to a projected $5,457 million in FY2024, with notable rises in recent years.
• Total external debt servicing (principal plus interest) rose from $4,155 million in FY2010 to a peak of $19,482 million in FY2023, with a projected reduction to $14,730 million in FY2024.
